title: One Model for ALL: Low-Level Task Interaction Is a Key to Task-Agnostic Image Fusion
author: Chunyang Cheng (Jiangnan University), Tianyang Xu (Jiangnan University), Zhenhua Feng (Jiangnan University), Xiaojun Wu (Jiangnan University), Zhangyong Tang (Jiangnan University), Hui Li (Jiangnan University), Zeyang Zhang (Jiangnan University), ..., Josef Kittler (University of Surrey)
relevance_why: The paper presents a new approach to image fusion that could be applicable to scenarios where visual representations are necessary in audio processing, such as audio-visual alignment tasks.
background: Image fusion combines information from multiple images to create a more informative output, relevant in fields like remote sensing and medical imaging.
contribution: This paper introduces the Generalised Image Fusion Network (GIFNet) to solve the challenges in effective image fusion, achieving high performance in various seen and unseen tasks using a single model.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods relied heavily on high-level semantics and required separate models for different fusion tasks, which limited their adaptability and efficiency.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by employing low-level task interactions through a three-branch architecture that integrates digital photography and multi-modal fusion without high-level task dependencies.

key_innovation: The integration of low-level tasks promotes feature learning at the pixel level, enhancing the performance of the model across various image fusion scenarios.
real_world_impact: This method simplifies the deployment of image processing applications on devices with limited resources and supports versatile image enhancement capabilities, broadening its use in real-world scenarios.
limitations: The paper does not mention specific limitations.

new_terms.Generalised Image Fusion Network (GIFNet: **GIFNet** is a model designed for multi-task image fusion that employs low-level task interactions to enhance feature extraction and adaptability across various fusion scenarios.
